articles.headline: Japanese Consumers Reconsidering Rice Loyalty
articles.snippet: Prompted by declining incomes, as well as fears about radiation, more Japanese consumers and businesses are fighting for the tiny available amounts of imported rice.
articles.abstract: Prompted by declining incomes, as well as fears about radiation, more Japanese consumers and businesses are fighting for the tiny available amounts of imported rice.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In the four months that Seiyu Walmart, as the big American retailer’s stores are known here, has been selling low-cost Chinese rice, it has struggled to keep shelves stocked at some stores. A Japanese chain, Beisia, also sold Chinese-grown rice for the first time this year but quickly ran out.

articles.headline: Accounting Détente Delayed
articles.snippet: A meeting this week of the world’s two major accounting boards revealed the divisions that prevent agreement on a single set of rules.
articles.abstract: A meeting this week of the world’s two major accounting boards revealed the divisions that prevent agreement on a single set of rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I’m the decider,” George W. Bush once famously said. “I decide what is best.”

articles.headline: Border Posts Fall Into the Hands of Syrian Rebels
articles.snippet: Building on momentum gained by their brazen assassination of three top Syrian security officials a day earlier, rebel fighters seized all four crossings with Iraq and one into Turkey.
articles.abstract: Building on momentum gained by their brazen assassination of three top Syrian security officials a day earlier, rebel fighters seized all four crossings with Iraq and one into Turkey.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rebel fighters in Syria, building on the momentum gained by their brazen assassination of three top security officials a day earlier, seized all four border crossings with Iraq and one into Turkey on Thursday, while also claiming for the first time to have captured a pocket of Damascus after intense street fighting.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Tim Arango

articles.headline: A Hunt for Split-Ticket Voters in a Tight Virginia Senate Race
articles.snippet: For former Gov. Tim Kaine and ex-Senator George Allen, the search for people who say their vote for senator is not tied to their vote for president has become imperative.
articles.abstract: For former Gov. Tim Kaine and ex-Senator George Allen, the search for people who say their vote for senator is not tied to their vote for president has become imperative.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, Va. — Like so many others in Appalachia, Amelia Trent’s vote is tied to coal, and when it comes to the coal industry and her economic future, Ms. Trent does not trust President Obama.

articles.headline: Legal Battles Erupt Over Tough Voter ID Laws
articles.snippet: Lawsuits over voter identification laws could affect millions of voters, as opponents of the laws argue that they suppress minority votes and supporters say they prevent fraud.
articles.abstract: Lawsuits over voter identification laws could affect millions of voters, as opponents of the laws argue that they suppress minority votes and supporters say they prevent fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Four years ago as Viviette Applewhite, now 93, was making her way through her local Acme supermarket, her pocketbook hanging from her shoulder, a thief sliced the bag from its straps.

articles.headline: Gunman Kills 12 in Colorado, Reviving Gun Debate
articles.snippet: After a movie theater shooting that left at least 12 dead and 58 wounded, witnesses described a scene of claustrophobia, panic and blood.
articles.abstract: After a movie theater shooting that left at least 12 dead and 58 wounded, witnesses described a scene of claustrophobia, panic and blood.
articles.lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — Anticipation built in the packed, darkened movie theater. Life and its cares began to recede.
articles.byline: By Dan Frosch and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: European Agency Backs Approval of a Gene Therapy
articles.snippet: The therapy, which would treat a rare disease, could be the first regulatory approval of a gene therapy in the Western world.
articles.abstract: The therapy, which would treat a rare disease, could be the first regulatory approval of a gene therapy in the Western world.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than two decades of dashed expectations, the field of gene therapy appears close to reaching a milestone: a regulatory approval.

articles.headline: Cameras Are Cyclists’ ‘Black Boxes’ in Accidents
articles.snippet: Footage from cameras used by bicyclists to document their rides has begun to play a role in police investigations of accidents, local authorities said.
articles.abstract: Footage from cameras used by bicyclists to document their rides has begun to play a role in police investigations of accidents, local authorities said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Evan Wilder went flying onto the pavement during his bicycle commute one morning here, he didn’t have time to notice the license plate of the pickup truck that had sideswiped him after its driver hurled a curse at him. Nor did a witness driving another car.

articles.headline: Bond Rates in Spain Inch Higher Amid Fears
articles.snippet: Spanish bond yields rose over 7 percent for a second day as an agreement to release 30 billion euros in bank aid left questions unanswered about the country’s financial health.
articles.abstract: Spanish bond yields rose over 7 percent for a second day as an agreement to release 30 billion euros in bank aid left questions unanswered about the country’s financial health.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Spanish borrowing costs rose to worrisome levels for a second day on Friday as the government said the economy would remain in recession through 2013 and the region of Valencia would need state financing.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: For UBS, a Record of Averting Prosecution
articles.snippet: The Swiss bank, one of more than a dozen being investigated for manipulating interest rates, has a trail of transgressions that makes it stand out from other banks.
articles.abstract: The Swiss bank, one of more than a dozen being investigated for manipulating interest rates, has a trail of transgressions that makes it stand out from other banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Justice Department weighs the possibility of criminal charges in the unfolding Libor rate-setting scandal, it may want to consider the record of the Swiss banking giant UBS.
